questions.title: Passage I
questions.article: The specific volume of a substance is defined as the volume occupied by a given mass of the stance. A substance's density equals I divided by the substance's specific volume. Figure 1 shows how the specific volume of water (in cubic centimeters per gram, cm3/g) varies with temperature, while Figure 2 shows how the specific volume of ethyl alcohol varies with temperature.
questions.question: 1. A glass of water is at 60°C. Based on Figure 1, if the temperature of the water drops to 40°C, its specific volume will:

choices.D: vary, but with no general trend.

questions.question: 5.  In addition to the unit representing specific volume that is given in the passage, which of the following units could be used to represent specific volume?

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:
Suppose light is shone on a thin film of oil floating on water. The reflected light will be almost as bright as the incident light (the light shone on the film) if the light undergoes constructive interference, and it will be much dimmer than the incident light if the light undergoes destructive interference.


Students conducted a series of studies to better understand the variables that affect interference.

Study 1
The students measured a small volume of a particular type of oil into a cylindrical tank of water, forming a film of depth D on the water's surface (see Figure 1).


They shone light at a frequency of 6.0 x 1014hertz (Hz) straight down onto the film and measured the brightness of the reflected light, B. They added more of the oil to the tank, measuring B and recording the total volume of oil in the tank after each addition.

The students used the known cross-sectional area of the tank and the total volume of oil in the tank to calculate D for each measured B. A graph of B versus D is shown in Figure 2.


Study 2
The students used different types of oil, each having a different index of refraction (a measure of the oil's tendency to bend light). For each oil, the students used the procedure from Study 1 to find D of the shallowest film that produced a maximum in B(see Table 1).


Study 3
The students used light of different frequencies and Oil W. For each light frequency, they followed the procedure from Study 1 to find D of the shallowest film that produced a maximum in B (see Table 2).
questions.question: 6. In Study 1, what was D of the shallowest film that produced a maximum in B ?

questions.question: 7. Based on Study 2, the index of refraction of the oil used in Study 1 was which of the following?

questions.question: 8. Based on the results of one of the studies, as light frequency increased, D of the shallowed film that produced a maximum in B:

choices.D: varied, but with no general trend.

questions.question: 9. In Study 1, if the students had continued to add oil to the 445 nm deep film, the next maximum in the brightness of reflected light most likely would have occurred at D closest to which of the following?

questions.article:

questions.question: 10. A student hypothesized that the oils used in the 3 studies were denser than water. Is this hypothesis consistent with the information given?

choices.A: Yes; each oil floated on the surface of the water.
choices.B: Yes; each oil sank to the bottom of the container.
choices.C: No; each oil floated on the surface of the water.
choices.D: No; each oil sank to the bottom of the container.

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:

questions.question: 11. For a new type of oil, D of the shallowest film that produced a maximum in B was 80 nm. Based on the results of Study 2, the index of refraction of this new type of oil was:

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:
In the human gut, E. coli bacteria break down lactose (milk sugar) into 2 sugars: glucose and galactose. Th reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme β-galactosidase.

The E coli gene lacZ contains information needed to synthesize β-galactosidase. lacZ is located within the lac operon (a portion of DNA). The lac operon also contains the lac operon operator (LOO), a DNA region that regulates lacZ (see Figure1).


If LOO is active, lacZ is active, so β-galactosidase is synthesized. If LOO is inactive, lacZ is inactive, so β-galactosidase is not synthesized. The activity of LOO is regulated by protein 1 (P1), a protein found in E. coli cells.

Three students propose models to describe the regulation of LOO by P1 in E. coli.

Student 1
If lactose is absent from a cell, P1 binds to LOO, inactivating LOO. If lactose is present, it binds to P1, causing a conformational change (shape change) in P1. As a result, P1 cannot bind to LOO. When P1 is not bound to LOO, LOO is active (see Figure 2).


Student 2
If lactose is absent from a cell, P1 cannot bind to LOO, so LOO is inactive. When lactose is present, it binds to P1, causing a conformational change in P1. As a result, P1 binds to LOO. When P1 is bound to LOO, LOO is active (see Figure 3).


Student 3
If lactose is absent from a cell, then galactose is also absent. If galactose is absent from a cell, then P1 cannot bind to LOO, so LOO is inactive. If lactose is present in a cell, a few lactose molecules break down into glucose and galactose without the presence of a catalyst. The galactose then binds to P1, causing a conformational change in P1. As a result, P1 binds to L OO. When P1 is bound to LOO, LOO is active (see Figure 4).



Figures adapted from Nell.A Campbell, Biology, 3rd ed. @1993 by Benjamin/Cummings Publishing Company, Inc.
questions.question: 12.  Students 1 and 2 agree that lactose binds to:

questions.question: 13. Based on Student 3's model, which of the following procedures will most likely inactivate an active LOO in an E. coli cell?

questions.question: 14. According to Student 2's model, if lactose is absent from an E. coli cell, LOO is:

choices.B: active, so β-galactosidase is not synthesized.
choices.D: inactive, so β-galactosidase is not synthesized.

questions.question: 15. Student 1 proposes that P1:

choices.A: activates LOO by binding to LOO.

choices.C: inactivates LOO by binding to LOO.
choices.D: inactivates lacZ by binding to lacZ.

questions.question: 16. Which student(s) propose(s) that P1 can bind to LOO in the absence of lactose and galactose?

questions.question: 17. Suppose that it is possible to introduce lactose into an E. coli cell, eliminate galactose from the cell, and ensure that galactose remains absent from the cell. Based on the information provided, which students would predict that LOO would be active, given these conditions?

questions.question: 18. Suppose that a mutant E. coli cell were to be discovered and that this mutant is NOT able to produce P1. Based on the information provided, which student(s) would predict that LOO would be active in this cell?

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
Some plants produce mannitol (a sugarlike molecule) when exposed to a high-salt solution. Mannitol production results in an increase in the solute concentration within the plant cells and thus a decrease in the net movement of water between the high-salt solution and the cytoplasm of the cells exposed to the high-salt solution.

To investigate this effect, researchers created 5 genetically identical tobacco plant lines that could not produce mannitol. They then used genetic engineering techniques to insert genes to transform 3 of the lines (M1, M2, and M3) into mannitol-producing lines (Ms). The fourth line (NMI) was also exposed to the genetic engineering procedures, but no genetic material was inserted into NMI. The fifth line (NM2) was not genetically engineered. Thus, NMI and NM2 were non-mannitol-producing lines (NMS). Two experiments were then conducted.

Experiment 1

Five 6-week-old plants from each line were grown for 10 days in a nutrient solution with a normal salt concentration. Each line had the same average height and mass at the start of the experiment. The average percent increase in height and mass during the experiment appears in Table 1.


Experiment 2

Five 6-week-old plants from each line were grown fo 30 days in a nutrient solution with a high salt concentration. Each line had the same average height and mass at the start of the experiment. The average percent changes in height and mass after 14 days and after 30 days appear in Table 2.


Tables adapted from MichellIC. Tarczynskl, Richard G, Jansen, and Hans J. Bohnert, "Stress Protection of Transgenic Tobacco by Production of the Osmolyte Mannitol." @1993 by the American Association for Advancement of Acience.
questions.question: 19.  If the raw data for the average mass of the 5 plant lines in Experiment 2 were plotted on the graph below and a best-fitting line was drawn for each of the 5 plant lines, how many of the best-fitting lines would have a positive slope and how many would have a negative slope?

choices.A: All 5 would have a positive slope.
choices.B: All 5 would have a negative slope.
choices.C: Two would have a negative slope and 3 would have a positive slope.
choices.D: Two would have a positive slope and 3 would have a negative slope.

Tables adapted from MichellIC. Tarczynskl, Richard G, Jansen, and Hans J. Bohnert, "Stress Protection of Transgenic Tobacco by Production of the Osmolyte Mannitol." @1993 by the American Association for Advancement of Acience.
questions.question: 20. Which line had the greatest average percent decrease in mass during the last 16 days of Experiment 2?

Mannitol production results in an increase in the solute concentration within the plant cells and thus a decrease in the net movement of water between the high-salt solution and the cytoplasm of the cells exposed to the high-salt solution.

To investigate this effect, researchers created 5 genetically identical tobacco plant lines that could not produce mannitol. They then used genetic engineering techniques to insert genes to transform 3 of the lines (M1, M2, and M3) into mannitol-producing lines (Ms). The fourth line (NMI) was also exposed to the genetic engineering procedures, but no genetic material was inserted into NMI. The fifth line (NM2) was not genetically engineered. Thus, NMI and NM2 were non-mannitol-producing lines (NMS). Two experiments were then conducted.

Experiment 1

Five 6-week-old plants from each line were grown for 10 days in a nutrient solution with a normal salt concentration. Each line had the same average height and mass at the start of the experiment. The average percent increase in height and mass during the experiment appears in Table 1.


Experiment 2

Five 6-week-old plants from each line were grown fo 30 days in a nutrient solution with a high salt concentration. Each line had the same average height and mass at the start of the experiment. The average percent changes in height and mass after 14 days and after 30 days appear in Table 2.


Tables adapted from MichellIC. Tarczynskl, Richard G, Jansen, and Hans J. Bohnert, "Stress Protection of Transgenic Tobacco by Production of the Osmolyte Mannitol." @1993 by the American Association for Advancement of Acience.
questions.question: 21. The net movement of water referred to in the passage occurred through which of the following structures?

questions.question: 22. Overall, how did the e average height of each of the 5 lines change during Experiment 2 ?

choices.A: It increased in each of the Ms and in each of the NMs.
choices.B: It decreased in each of the Ms and in each of the NMs.
choices.C: It increased in each of the Ms and decreased in each of the NMs.
choices.D: It decreased in each of the Ms and increased n each of the NMs.

questions.question: 23. The researchers were interested primarily in the relationship between mannitol production rates in salty conditions. Which of the following most likely best explains why the researchers con ducted Experiment 1? They wanted to determine whether Ms and NMS：

choices.A: grow at the same rate in a nutrient solution with a normal salt concentration.
choices.B: grow at the same rate in a nutrient solution with a high mannitol concentration.
choices.C: can grow in a nutrient solution with a high salt concentration.
choices.D: can grow in a nutrient solution with a low mannitol concentration.

questions.question: 24. In Experiment 1, which of the following were independent variables?I. Whether genes were inserted into a line II. Whether genetic engineering techniques were used on a lineIll. Whether the mass of a line changed during the experiment

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:
When a mixture is at equilibrium, no net phase changes occur. Figure 1 shows the phases of the metals gold (Au )and thallium (TI) present in various Au-TI mixtures at different temperatures and at equilibrium. The Au-TI mixtures contain only Au and Tl, so an Au-TI mixture that contains 60% Au will contain 40% Tl, and 100 g of this mixture will contain 60 g of Au and 40 g of Tl.


Figure 1 adapted from the National Research Council, International Critical Tables of Numerical Data, Physics, Chemistry and Technology; Volume II. @1927 by the McGraw-Hill Book Company, Inc.

A cooling curve shows how the phases of the metals in the mixture change as it cools over time. Figure 2 shows a cooling curve for an Au-TI mixture containing 58% Au. Figure 2 also explains how Figure 1 is related to Figure 2.
questions.question: 25. Based on Figures 1 and 2, for any given Au-TI mixture, the constant temperature region of a cooling curve will occur at which of the following temperatures?

questions.question: 26. According to Figure 2, which of the following best describes what occurs as an Au-TI mixture containing 58% Au at 900°C is cooled to 0°C in 1 hr? During the 1 hr, the temperature of the mixture will:

choices.C: decrease, then become constant, then decrease.

choices.A: 5% Au: solid TI not present60% Au: solid TI present

choices.D: 5% Au: solid TI present60% Au: solid TI present

questions.question: 28.  A chemist claimed that at 70°C, any Au-TI mixture at equilibrium will be completely composed of solids. Does Figure 1 support her claim?

choices.A: No, because all of the mixtures will be in Region I.
choices.B: No. because all of the mixtures will be in Region IV
choices.C: Yes, because all of the mixtures will be in Region I.
choices.D: Yes, because all of the mixtures will be in Region IV.

questions.question: 29. According to Figure 1, at equilibrium, the lowest temperature at which an Au-TI mixture containing 90% Au will be completely liquid is closest to which of the following?

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article: Figure 1 shows the relative ground elevation at Sites A-D in an earthquake-prone area, measured over 30 yr. Relative ground elevation is the vertical distance above or below the nearest benchmark (location of known, fixed elevation). Figure 2 shows the resistivity (which is directly proportion to the resistance to the flow of electrical current) of the bedrock in the same area, measured over 8 months (mo) in 1996. Figure 3 shows the level of the radon (a radioactive gas) emissions from well water in the same area, measured over 8 yr. The time at which an earthquake occurred in the area is indicated in all 3 figures.
questions.question: 30. Based on Figure 3, at the end of 1989, the level of radon emissions from the well water in the area studied was most likely closest to which of the following?

choices.A: North sites: Generally increasedSouth sites: Generally decreased
choices.B: North sites: Remained the sameSouth sites: Generally decreased
choices.C: North sites: Generally decreasedSouth sites: Generally increased
choices.D: North sites: Remained the sameSouth sites: Generally increased

Accordingly, based on Figure 1, which site was farthest from the epicenter?

questions.question: 34. Two cylindrical resistors were identical except for their material of construction. Resistor A was made from bedrock identical to the bedrock in the study area in May 1996. Resistor B was made from bedrock identical to the bedrock in the study area in July 1996. Each resistor was inserted, one at a time, in the following circuit.The electrical current in the circuit was greater when which resistor was in the circuit?

choices.A: Resistor A, because the bedrock collected in May 1996 had the higher resistivity.
choices.B: Resistor A, because the bedrock collected in May 1996 had the lower resistivity.
choices.C: Resistor B, because the bedrock collected in May 1996 had the higher resistivity.
choices.D: Resistor B, because the bedrock collected in May 1996 had the lower resistivity.

questions.title: Passage VII
questions.article:
Partial freezing is a water purification technique based on the fact that as a salt solution freezes, salts concentrate in the liquid phase. Thus, the solid that forms has a lower salt concentration than the remaining liquid.

Students measured the conductivity (ease of flow of electrical current through a substance) of aqueous solutions to study the partial freezing.

Experiment 1
A 100 g solution was made by dissolving 0.5 g of NaCl in distilled H2O. The conductivity of the solution was measured in millisiemens (mS) per cm at 13°C. The procedure was repeated for solutions with different NaCI concentrations (see Table 1).


Experiment 2
A beaker containing 20 mL of Solution 1 was stirred in a cold bath at -20°C. When approximately 25% of the solution was frozen, its liquid and solid portions were separated. The solid portion was then completely thawed, and both the solid and liquid portions were allowed to come to 13°C. The conductivity of each of the 2 portions was then measured. Additional trials were done by repeating this procedure, except that the liquid and solid portions were separated when the solution was approximately 50% and 75% frozen, respectively. These same procedures were then used for Solutions 2-6 (see Table 2).
questions.question: 35. Suppose an additional trial had been done with Solution 4 in which the liquid and solid portions of Solution 4 were separated when it was 60% frozen. The conductivities for the liquid and solid portions of the solution would most likely have been which of the following?

questions.question: 36. Suppose an additional NaCl solution had been tested in Experiment 2. If, in the trial in which the solution was 25% frozen, the conductivity of the liquid portion was 15.2 mS/cm, then, based on Experiment 1, the NaCl concentration of the solution before freezing was most likely:

questions.question: 37. How would the boiling point of Solution 2 have compared to the boiling point of Solution 4 The boiling point of Solution 2 would have been:

choices.A: lower, because Solution 2 had a higher solute concentration than did Solution 4.
choices.B: lower, because Solution 2 had a lower solute concentration than did Solution 4.
choices.C: higher, because Solution 2 had a higher solute concentration than did Solution 4.
choices.D: higher, because Solution 2 had a lower solute concentration than did Solution 4.

questions.question: 38. Which of the following, if true, would have been a flaw in the design of Experiment 2?

choices.A: The average conductivity of the solutions was greater than 40 mS/cm.
choices.B: The device used to measure conductivity had a usable range of only 0-120 mS/cm.
choices.C: The NaCl concentration of Solution 5 was lower than that of Solution 6.
choices.D: The freezing point of some of the solutions was lower than-20°C.
